descriptions.content:
A verb is said to be “factitive” when its agent causes an action to be performed by another agent, or has the subject perform the action. In English, the factitive is often expressed by the auxiliary “to have” or “to make” (someone do something). The Tibetan factitive construction may also be translated by “to let” (someone do something).

The usual factitive construction is: Verb + རུ་ + འཇུག་.

A factitive transformation is made by placing after the verb the suffix རུ་, which corresponds to one of the (literary) forms of the oblique, followed by the verb འཇུག་, the past tense of which is བཅུག་. In Literary Tibetan, the form of the oblique is modified according to the last letter of the preceding verb. In the spoken language, however, the particle may often be omitted altogether in the construction.

  • སྐད་བརྒྱབ་(རུ་)འཇུག་ “To make somebody shout”
  • སྐད་བརྒྱག་ཏུ་འཇུག་ “To make somebody shout” (L)
  • མོ་རང་གིས་ལས་ཀ་བྱེད་(རུ་)འཇུག་གི་མི་འདུག “She doesn’t let me work.”
  • ངས་ཁོང་ཡི་གེ་འབྲི་(རུ་)བཅུག་པ་ཡིན། “I made him write a letter.”
